4.1.1.title: Basic Hydrostatic Pressure
4.1.1.content:
**Formula:**
```
Hydrostatic Pressure (psi) = Mud Weight (ppg) × 0.052 × TVD (ft)
```

**The 0.052 constant:**
- Converts ppg to psi/ft
- 1 ppg exerts 0.052 psi per foot of depth

**Example:**
Mud Weight = 12.0 ppg
TVD = 10,000 ft

Hydrostatic = 12.0 × 0.052 × 10,000 = 6,240 psi

**Metric:**
```
Hydrostatic Pressure (bar) = Mud Weight (sg) × 0.0981 × TVD (m)
```

4.1.2.title: Equivalent Mud Weight (EMW)
4.1.2.content:
**Converting Pressure to EMW:**
```
EMW (ppg) = Pressure (psi) ÷ 0.052 ÷ TVD (ft)
```

**Use:**
- Express formation pressure as equivalent density
- Compare pressures at different depths
- Determine required mud weight

**Example:**
Formation pressure = 5,720 psi at 10,000 ft TVD

EMW = 5,720 ÷ 0.052 ÷ 10,000 = 11.0 ppg

This formation requires minimum 11.0 ppg mud to balance.

4.1.3.title: Pressure Gradient
4.1.3.content:
**Gradient (psi/ft):**
```
Gradient = Mud Weight (ppg) × 0.052
```

**Common Gradients:**
| Fluid | Density | Gradient |
|-------|---------|----------|
| Fresh water | 8.33 ppg | 0.433 psi/ft |
| Seawater | 8.55 ppg | 0.445 psi/ft |
| 10 ppg mud | 10.0 ppg | 0.52 psi/ft |
| 12 ppg mud | 12.0 ppg | 0.624 psi/ft |
| 16 ppg mud | 16.0 ppg | 0.832 psi/ft |

**Use:**
Multiply gradient by depth to get pressure.

4.1.4.title: Composite Columns
4.1.4.content:
**Multiple Fluids in Column:**
When different fluids are in the wellbore, calculate each separately and sum.

```
Total HP = HP₁ + HP₂ + HP₃ + ...
```

**Example:**
Seawater: 5,000 ft at 8.55 ppg
Mud: 7,000 ft at 12.0 ppg

HP(seawater) = 8.55 × 0.052 × 5,000 = 2,223 psi
HP(mud) = 12.0 × 0.052 × 7,000 = 4,368 psi

Total = 2,223 + 4,368 = 6,591 psi

4.1.5.title: Bottom Hole Pressure
4.1.5.content:
**Static BHP:**
```
BHP = Hydrostatic Pressure at TVD
```

**Circulating BHP (includes ECD):**
```
BHP = Hydrostatic + Annular Friction Loss
```

**During Well Control:**
```
BHP = Hydrostatic + Surface Pressure (at choke)
```

**Key Principle:**
Maintaining constant BHP during kill operations is the fundamental goal of well control.
